newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania opposition faces tough choices on alliance.
newsitem.headline: Romania opposition faces tough choices on alliance.

text.p: Romania's anti-Communist opposition is poised to take control of government after a resounding general election victory but tough negotiations remain ahead to form a workable coalition.

With official results reported from nearly three-quarters of Romania's 15,000 polling stations, the centrist Democratic Convention (CDR) had some 30 percent of the vote, thrashing the ex-Communists of president Ion Iliescu, with 23 percent.

It remained unclear who would emerge as president. Iliescu led a field of 16 in Sunday's voting with 33 percent and went through to a November 17 run-off with the CDR's leader, professor Emil Constantinescu.

The Convention, which has accused Iliescu's cautious reforms of creating mass poverty, was euphoric about turfing his Party of Social Democracy (PDSR) out of office and implementing its "Contract with Romania" of faster reforms.
Its most likely coalition partner is former Prime Minister Petre Roman, third in the presidential race with 20 percent.
But the Convention made it clear it expected Roman to endorse Constantinescu in the run-off round for the presidency as the price of allowing it into government.

"First we must have concrete support for the presidential campaign," CDR campaign manager Remus Opris told state television. "That is a key element to strengthen our relations and help negotations on a coalition."
Constantinescu's relations with Roman are cool at best.
He attacked Roman in the campaign, demanding explanations for "serious errors" during 22 months in office in the aftermath of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's 1989 execution.
But the CDR's options are limited as it has rejected outright any alliance with Iliescu's PDSR.
The only other groups clearing the three percent minimum barrier into parliament are a party representing 1.6 million ethnic Hungarians and two extreme nationalist parties.

Constantinescu received support in the presidential run-off from an unexpected quarter -- one of the two nationalists, Gheorghe Funar, the mayor of the Transylvanian city of Cluj, accused of curbing the rights of the Hungarian minority.
"If I have to choose between two evils, let it be Constantinescu," he told private ProTV television.
Other coalition combinations remain possible, including a minority CDR government relying on tactical support from Roman's Social Democrats and the Hungarian party.
Analysts warned that a CDR-led government would have to abandon populist promises and take unpopular measures to kick-start the weak Romanian economy.

"The new government will have to rebalance the economy by restructuring, allowing prices to rise and accepting a further depreciation of the leu (currency), independent economist Ilie Serbanescu told Reuters.

Iliescu's opponents say his cautious approach to reforms plunged millions of Romanians into poverty and left the country well behind its neighbours opting for a fast-track approach to the market -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
